reviews.text: It's a bit of a walk from the town center but it does its job barely as a train station. Step free access is only available for trains heading towards Ascot locations, not for Guildford or Aldershot. Tickets machines are provided as well as a free car park but the ticket office is only open part time. Trains usually run every half an hour throughout the day.

Not a very accessible station. The only way to the second platform is by footbridge. So not very practical for wheelchair users or pushchairs. We had to carry our double buggy across the bridge which was only just possible with two of us.

Beautiful, quiet station tucked away in the quaint town of Bagshot, after which "Bathilda Bagshot" was named in the popular fantasy children's novel series "Harry Potter". There is no known link between the books' author, JK Rowling, and the small Surrey village so one can only assume she was inspired by the gorgeous 60s-era architecture of the station. The class 456 trains which operate here regularly (on a half-hourly basis in both directions, towards Guildford and Ascot!) really add the the dystopian "1984" feel. Incidentally, the trainsets themselves were built in the 1990s, only marginally exceeding the time which Bagshot feels permanently locked in. I recommend everyone visits here at some point. Make use of the multi-purpose area where one can take a bike at any time, and have a ride in the nearby Swinley forest, before returning to the station and making use of Bagshot's fantastic rail links.
